text: Andrea Bowers explores the histories of modern art and activism across a range of issues, taking particular interest in workers’ rights, sexuality, discrimination, and immigration. In this monumental drawing on repurposed cardboard, Bowers evokes the figure of the Bugler Girl, the emblem of the National Union of Women’s Suffrage Societies. These popular organizations lobbied for women’s voting rights as part of the Suffrage Movement in the United Kingdom (1897–1918). Despite its lofty aims, this movement—and its corollary in the United States during the same period—often excluded or otherwise marginalized nonwhite women’s rights. In a restorative gesture, Bowers reimagines the Bugler Girl as a woman of color, transforming the call to action to embrace all women.
title: National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies
